title: 104_s1241
content: The Public Broadcasting Financial Independence and Family Viewing Act of 1995 establishes guidelines for family-friendly programming on public broadcasting, prohibits the use of federal funds for indecent or nudity-inclusive programs, and emphasizes the importance of educational and entertaining content suitable for family viewing. Section 396(a) of title 47 is amended to include a new subsection emphasizing the importance of public broadcasting providing educational, cultural, informational, and entertaining programming suitable for family viewing. SEC. 5. SPECTRUM FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will allow public broadcast license holders to use their spectrum for ancillary services, ensuring proceeds benefit public broadcasting and commitments are maintained. Fees for non-broadcasting use will be at market rates. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. SEC. 6. SCHEDULE FLEXIBILITY. The Commission will regulate public broadcast license holders to offer non-public broadcast programming for a fee between 1 a.m. and 6 a.m. Proceeds must benefit public broadcasting, existing commitments must be maintained, and fees for non-public broadcasting use must be at market rates. SEC. 7. ENHANCED UNDERWRITING. Amends sections of title 47 to allow for calls to action, inducements to buy, sell, rent, or lease, and provision of price information in promotions. SEC. 8. SATELLITE, COMMON CARRIER AND OTHER FORMS OF PROGRAM DISTRIBUTION. Public Broadcasting programming can be distributed via satellite, common carrier, or other telecommunications technology for a fee, with proceeds benefiting public broadcasting. The Commission can approve frequency exchanges between public and commercial broadcasters for the benefit of the national public broadcasting system. Agreements for programming should include provisions for public broadcasting to share in benefits from ancillary products. The General Accounting Office will review the operations of public broadcasting entities and make recommendations for improvement. They will also study the feasibility of merging public broadcasting with international broadcasting operations. Additionally, educational rates will be addressed. The General Accounting Office will conduct a feasibility study on merging public broadcasting operations with international broadcasting operations of the United States Government. Public broadcast licensees may qualify for educational telecommunications service rates for providing public broadcasting.
